name: lidocaine
source: Hughes LD; Palmer DS; Nigsch F and Mitchell JBO. 2008 Why are some properties more difficult to predict than others? A study of QSPR models of solubility; melting point and LogP. J. Chem. Inf. Model. 2008. 48 (1). pp 220?459

name: lidocaine
source: Hughes LD; Palmer DS; Nigsch F and Mitchell JBO. 2008 Why are some properties more difficult to predict than others? A study of QSPR models of solubility; melting point and LogP. J. Chem. Inf. Model. 2008. 48 (1). pp 220?459
Reason: Lidocaine has several functional groups that influence its melting point. The base structure can be considered as aniline which has a melting point of around 6 degrees Celsius. The amide group typically raises the melting point by about 80-100 degrees because it can form hydrogen bonds and has a planar, rigid structure. Two methyl groups on one of the amino groups add steric bulk but may not significantly raise the melting point, perhaps contributing an additional 5-10 degrees. Another two methyl groups on the aromatic ring may contribute similarly with an additional 5-10 degrees. An additional ethyl chain may add a little in terms of London dispersion forces, possibly contributing another 5 degrees. So, from the base point of aniline at 6 degrees, we add the contributions from the amide and the alkyl groups.
Prediction: Considering the base melting point of aniline (6), the addition of the amide group (+90), methyl group contributions (+20 total for four methyl groups), and ethyl chain (+5), the predicted melting point of lidocaine is approximately 121 degrees Celsius.

name: lidocaine
source: Hughes LD; Palmer DS; Nigsch F and Mitchell JBO. 2008 Why are some properties more difficult to predict than others? A study of QSPR models of solubility; melting point and LogP. J. Chem. Inf. Model. 2008. 48 (1). pp 220?459
Reason: Lidocaine's melting point is influenced by various functional groups. Aniline, a similar basic structure, has a melting point of around 6 degrees Celsius. The amide group is likely to raise the melting point significantly (approximately +80 due to its ability to form hydrogen bonds and its rigid structure). Each of the four methyl groups may contribute a smaller increase to the melting point (estimated at +5 for each, so +20 in total). The additional ethyl chain is expected to have a minor effect on the melting point, potentially adding another few degrees (approximately +5 due to increased molecular weight and van der Waals interactions). Summing these adjustments to aniline's melting point results in a predicted melting point for lidocaine.
Prediction: 111 degrees Celsius (Starting with aniline's 6 degrees Celsius, +80 for the amide group, +20 for the methyl groups, and +5 for the ethyl chain)

name: lidocaine
source: Hughes LD; Palmer DS; Nigsch F and Mitchell JBO. 2008 Why are some properties more difficult to predict than others? A study of QSPR models of solubility; melting point and LogP. J. Chem. Inf. Model. 2008. 48 (1). pp 220?459
Reason: Lidocaine consists of several functional groups and structural features that affect its melting point: an aromatic ring, an amide bond, two tertiary amine groups, and two ethyl groups. The basic aromatic unit we can take as a reference might be benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5°C. The two methyl groups directly attached to the aromatic ring (toluene-like structure) would typically increase the melting point due to the added hydrophobic bulk (+30 each). The amide bond usually increases the melting point due to its ability to form hydrogen bonds (+40). However, the two tertiary amine groups and ethyl groups are aliphatic chains which may lower the melting point due to increased flexibility and entropy (-5 each for the amine groups as well as for the ethyl groups). Since the structure induces some steric hindrance which may disrupt crystal packing, we consider an additional reduction in melting point (-10).
